name: Automatic Text Summarization with Machine Learning - An overview

tasks.body: What are use cases of summarization?
Why do we want to automate it?
What are the two main approaches for automatic summarization?
How does the extractive approach generally work?
tasks.answer: Sentences are given a relevance score and the summary is comprised of the sentences with the highest scores.

tasks.body: How does the abstractive approach generally work?
tasks.answer: First the text is encoded in some intermediate abstract form and then the summary is newly generated text based on the representation in the abstract latent space.

tasks.body: Which of the two approaches is simpler?
tasks.answer: Extractive.

tasks.body: Which approach can be expected to generate better results if done well?
tasks.answer: Abstractive

tasks.body: What are the benefits of the abstractive approach?
tasks.answer: The output is not limited to the sentences and words provided by the input text. The summary can be more concise when new sentences are generated.

name: Productivity and Growth: Crash Course Economics #6

tasks.body: What does GDP stand for?
tasks.answer: Gross domestic product

tasks.body: How are countries generally classified into rich and poor?
tasks.answer: Based on their GDP per capita.

tasks.body: What is GDP per capita?
tasks.answer: The GDP of a country divided by the number of residents.

tasks.body: Can a country with higher GDP be considered poorer than one with lower GDP?
tasks.answer: Yes, a country with higher GDP but more residents can have a lower GDP per capita.

tasks.body: How do the GDP per capita and standards of living in a country correlate?
tasks.answer: In general there is a positive correlation. So countries with a higher GDP per capita have better standards of living.

tasks.body: Role of natural resources for GDP per capita?
What is the driving factor for a high GDP per capita?
tasks.answer: Productivity

tasks.body: What is productivity?
tasks.answer: The amount of value produced by a person in a given amount of time.

tasks.body: What is required for high productivity (factors of production)?
answer: Land, which includes all natural resources.
Capital, which includes machines, factories and infrastructure.
Human Capital, the workers education, knowledges and skills.

tasks.body: What is technology?
tasks.answer: The sum total of knowledge and information that society has acquired concerning the use of resources to produce goods and services.

tasks.body: How does technology influence productivity?
tasks.answer: Better technology increases productivity because goods and services can be produced faster, better and/or cheaper.

tasks.body: When did computers at workplaces really start to become productivity boosters?
tasks.answer: When they were connected to form the internet.

tasks.body: Approximately how many cups of coffee at once would be deadly?
Why can people drink more coffee than that in their lifetime?
tasks.answer: The human body has ways to get rid of the dangerous substances. Caffeine gets metabolized by the liver into other organic molecules.

tasks.body: Why are cyanide packed apple seeds not dangerous even though the body can only tolerate very small amounts of it?
tasks.answer: Our body converts it to vitamin B12 very quickly before large amounts of it build up?

tasks.body: Why is lead dangerous even though our body can tolerate much more of it than cyanide?
tasks.answer: It takes much longer for lead to leave the body, because it gets stored in bones. So it builds up over time.

tasks.body: How much water input can the body deal with at once?
tasks.answer: About 6 liters.

tasks.body: What source of energy is used to heat almost every building in Iceland?
tasks.answer: Geothermal

tasks.body: How is the segment between the earths core and its crust called?
tasks.answer: Mantle

tasks.body: In what range are the temperatures in the mantle?
tasks.answer: 1000 - 3500 degrees Celsius

tasks.body: Where does the heat in the mantle come from?
tasks.answer: Some from the radioactive decay of metals and much of it from earths core.

tasks.body: What role does water play when extracting heat from earth?
tasks.answer: Generally, cold water goes down, heats up, and comes up when it is hot.

tasks.body: What are the two main approaches for extracting geothermal energy?
tasks.answer: Geothermal powerplant and heat pumps

tasks.body: How does a geothermal powerplant work?
tasks.answer: Extracts hot steam from earths mantle, sends it through a generator and lets the cooled down water to back into the mantle. The generator generates electricity.

tasks.body: How deep does one have to drill for such a powerplant?
tasks.answer: Several kilometers

tasks.body: How deep does one have to drill to benefit from earths temperature?
tasks.answer: Already a few meters under ground the temperature is quite stable and can be used to heat homes.

tasks.body: How do geothermal heat pumps work?
tasks.answer: Water or antifreeze liquid is pumped through earth a few meters deep. The warmed liquid is then pumped back up to distribute the heat.

tasks.body: Do geothermal heat pumps need external electricity input?
tasks.answer: yes

tasks.body: Why is the electricity used to pump the liquid not directly used to generate heat?
tasks.answer: Extracting heat from earth is more efficient. The energy extracted is much more than the energy put into the system.

tasks.body: How much energy does earth radiate on average?
tasks.answer: About 3 times as much as used by humanity.

tasks.body: How much of our energy comes from geothermal sources?
tasks.answer: About 0.2%.

tasks.body: Why is geothermal not used much more?
tasks.answer: The cost effectiveness of geothermal sources highly depends on the location on earth.

tasks.body: Approximately, how much does it cost to drill a few km deep for a geothermal powerplant?
tasks.answer: Up to 20 million us dollars.

tasks.body: What are possible negative side effects of drilling deep?
tasks.answer: Could trigger earth quakes and release pollutions into the environment.

tasks.body: What emerging technologies can help with these problems?
tasks.answer: Emission control systems can capture pollutants and electrodynamic monitoring can help detect seismic risks.
